mdRecord.dcterms:title: Virginia & Truckee Railroad Company No. 18 Dayton Locomotive, general view
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: The Dayton, a 4-4-0 "American", was built in 1873 by the Central Pacific Railroad, in Sacramento, California, and was based on the design of the CP's 173 engine. The locomotive weighs 78,000 pounds (35,000 kg), has 60 inches (150 cm) driving wheels, and carried 2,500 US gallons (9,500 l; 2,100 imp gal) of water and 3 cords of wood. A large snow plow was fixed to the front of the locomotive in 1879, and it performed snow clearing duties on the Virginia & Truckee lines during the winters for most of its operational life, in addition to its normal passenger hauling duties. .... In 2005, the Dayton was moved to the Comstock History Center in Virginia City, Nevada, where it is on static display. -- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_and_Truckee_18_Dayton [work]
mdRecord.dcterms:subject: Science, Technology and Industry
